Patient identification 

Name: M.S.  |  Age: 58  |  Sex: Male  |  Date/Source: 14 Jan 2026; ambulance arrival ~90 minutes from pain onset. 

 

Presenting complaint 

Severe central chest pain radiating to left arm and jaw, 60–90 minutes, with diaphoresis and nausea.

Crushing chest pain (9/10) began on exertion, constant, unrelieved by rest. No prior similar pain. Paramedics gave aspirin 300 mg. 

 

Past medical history 

Hypertension; hyperlipidaemia. No known diabetes. No prior MI/PCI/CABG. 

 

Past surgical history 

Appendectomy (remote). 

 

Family & social history 

Father MI at 62. Ex?smoker (30 pack?years, quit 5 years ago). No alcohol or drugs. 

 

Medications 

Amlodipine 10 mg OD; atorvastatin 20 mg nocte. 

 

Allergies 

No known drug allergies. 

 

Review of systems 

No fever/cough. No GI bleeding. 

 

Examination (on arrival) 

Vitals: HR 92, BP 138/84, RR 20, SpO? 96% RA; afebrile. General: diaphoretic. Cardio: S1/S2, no new murmur. Lungs: clear. No shock. 

 

Initial investigations 

12?lead ECG: 3 mm ST elevation V2–V4 with inferior reciprocal depression ? anterior STEMI. Reperfusion eligibility regardless of age/sex/ethnicity; deliver therapy as quickly as possible.  Labs for baseline; do not delay reperfusion. 

 

Focused management?linked investigations/decisions 

• Aspirin: single 300 mg loading dose given pre?hospital. 

• Reperfusion: primary PCI preferred if presentation ?12 h and PCI can be delivered within 120 min of the time fibrinolysis could have been given (radial access preferred). 

• Second antiplatelet for primary PCI: prasugrel with aspirin if not on OAC (consider ticagrelor or clopidogrel based on bleeding risk/OAC status; age ?75 may favour ticagrelor/clopidogrel). 

• Antithrombin: unfractionated heparin (radial) with bailout GPI as needed; consider bivalirudin if femoral access/bleeding risk. 

• Stent: drug?eluting stent if stenting indicated. 

 

Interpretation 

Early?presenting anterior STEMI meeting criteria for immediate primary PCI within the recommended time window. 

 

 

Diagnosis 

Acute ST?segment elevation myocardial infarction (anterior), primary PCI pathway.

Name: F.A.  |  Age: 72  |  Sex: Female  |  Source: ED self?presentation with chest pain at rest. 

 

Presenting complaint 

Recurrent rest chest tightness (20–30 min episodes) over 6 hours with mild dyspnoea. 

 

History of present illness 

Three episodes of retrosternal pressure at rest; last episode ongoing at arrival. No pre?diagnosis DAPT was given (appropriate). Risk factors: age, HTN, CKD3a, prior PCI 3 years ago. 

 

Past medical history 

Hypertension; CKD stage 3a; prior NSTEMI with PCI (DES to RCA). No AF. 

 

Past surgical history 

Cholecystectomy. 

 

Family & social history 

Non?smoker; lives with spouse. 

 

Medications 

Aspirin 75 mg OD; ramipril 5 mg; bisoprolol 5 mg; atorvastatin 40 mg. 

 

Allergies 

None known. 

 

Examination 

Vitals: HR 88, BP 146/84, RR 18, SpO? 97%. No heart failure signs. 

 

Initial investigations 

ECG: horizontal ST depression 1–2 mm in V4–V6 and T?wave inversion in II, aVF (dynamic). High?sensitivity troponin elevated and rising ? NSTEMI. 

 

Early pharmacology in ED 

Aspirin loading 300 mg (if not given) then indefinite. Antithrombin: fondaparinux (no high bleeding risk; not for immediate angiography). If severe renal impairment, consider UFH. If proceeding to PCI, administer systemic UFH in cath lab. 

 

Risk assessment 

Formal GRACE risk scoring (age, vitals, ECG, troponin, creatinine, prior MI/PCI) to estimate 6?month mortality and stratify (intermediate/high ?3%). 

 

Invasive strategy 

Offer early coronary angiography within 72 h for intermediate/high risk, or immediate angiography if unstable. If angiography/PCI and no OAC: prasugrel or ticagrelor with aspirin (prasugrel only after anatomy defined and PCI intended; weigh bleeding risk age ?75). If OAC indicated, choose clopidogrel as the second agent. Use DES if stenting indicated; consider GPI for complex PCI. 

 

Interpretation 

NSTEMI with dynamic ST changes and positive troponin at elevated risk ? angiography ?72 h with guideline?directed antithrombin and antiplatelet therapy. 

 

 

 

Diagnosis 

Non?ST?Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI), intermediate–high risk, early invasive pathway.

CASE 9  

 

Patient Identification 

Name: A.M., Age: 71, Sex: Male 

 

Presenting Complaint 

Progressive shortness of breath, orthopnoea, and ankle swelling for 6 months. 

 

History of Present Illness 

A 71-year-old man with progressive exertional dyspnoea, worsening orthopnoea (3 pillows), reduced exercise tolerance (NYHA II?III), paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, and progressive ankle oedema. Fatigue and abdominal bloating present. No chest pain or wheeze.

Hypertension, Type 2 diabetes, Hyperlipidaemia.

Amlodipine, Simvastatin, Metformin.

Raised JVP, bibasal crackles, displaced apex beat, mid-shin oedema.

NT-proBNP: 1,180 ng/L; ECG: LVH; CXR cardiomegaly; Echo LVEF 35%. 

 

Diagnosis 

Chronic Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF).

Patient Identification 

Name: M.H., Age: 59, Sex: Male 

 

Presenting Complaint 

Persistent exercise intolerance. 

 

History of Present Illness 

Six weeks post-acute pulmonary oedema. LVEF 30%. NYHA II–III despite therapy.

Hypertension, CKD stage 3a.

Ramipril, Bisoprolol, Furosemide, Atorvastatin. 

 

Examination 

Stable, BP 118/70, HR 76.

Initiate all four foundational therapies: ACEi, beta-blocker, MRA, SGLT2 inhibitor. If still symptomatic, switch ACEi ? ARNI (36-hour washout). Monitor renal function and electrolytes 1–2 weeks post-titration.

When starting a 59-year-old male with heart failure (LVEF 30%) and CKD stage 3a on ACE inhibitor, beta-blocker, mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA), and SGLT2 inhibitor, the following monitoring steps are essential:

1. Baseline Observations
Obtain baseline vital signs and laboratory values before starting therapy.
Assess for any history of allergy to the medications.
2. Medication Administration and Documentation
Ensure right documentation in the Medication Administration Record (MAR) after each administration.
Adhere to standard precautions during medication administration.
Medications should be administered as soon as possible after preparation or within their stability range.
Verify expiry date and visually inspect medications for discoloration or particulates before administration.
3. Monitoring for Adverse Drug Reactions (ADRs)
Monitor the patient for response to each medication, especially the first dose.
If any unusual or noxious reactions/allergies occur, notify the prescriber and clinical pharmacist immediately.
If an ADR is suspected, fill out the ADR form and follow the hospital’s ADR handling policy.
The treating physician and clinical pharmacist will decide on dose modification or discontinuation if needed, and a new order will be documented.
4. Ongoing Monitoring
Continue to monitor for side effects, especially with high-alert medications (e.g., MRAs).
For high-alert medications, two nurses must verify preparation and both must initial the medication record.
If there is any doubt about dose, route, or administration, consult the treating physician and clinical pharmacist.
5. Special Circumstances for Documentation
Record the exact time of administration if there is a discrepancy of more than 30 minutes from the scheduled time, or when peak/trough levels are being drawn, or for the first dose.
6. Patient Education
Provide patient education about each medication, including frequency, route, side effects, and special instructions.
Allow the patient to ask questions and provide answers through the assigned nurse, clinical pharmacist, or treating physician.
7. Securing Medication Records
Ensure medication records are secured when not in use to maintain patient confidentiality.
Key Laboratory and Clinical Parameters to Monitor:

Renal function (serum creatinine, eGFR) and electrolytes (especially potassium) due to risk of hyperkalemia and worsening renal function with ACE inhibitors, MRAs, and SGLT2 inhibitors.
Blood pressure and heart rate, particularly with beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors.
Signs of volume depletion or hypotension, especially with SGLT2 inhibitors and ACE inhibitors.
Blood glucose, especially if the patient is diabetic and on SGLT2 inhibitors.

gold_response: TSAT <20%, Ferritin <100 ng/mL.

anas_response:
Laboratory Tests and Thresholds for Diagnosing Iron Deficiency in HFrEF

To diagnose iron deficiency in a patient with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and new reduction in functional capacity, the following laboratory tests are typically used:

Serum Ferritin
Transferrin Saturation (TSAT)
Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)
Serum Iron
Key Abbreviations:

TIBC: Total Iron Binding Capacity
Tg: Triglycerides (not directly related to iron deficiency but may appear in lab panels)
TSAT: Not explicitly listed, but calculated from serum iron and TIBC
Thresholds: While the specific thresholds for iron deficiency in HFrEF are not detailed in the provided documents, standard practice often uses:

Serum Ferritin <100 ng/mL or
Serum Ferritin 100–299 ng/mL with TSAT <20%
Step-by-Step Guidance:

Order laboratory tests for serum ferritin, serum iron, and TIBC.
Calculate TSAT using the formula: (Serum Iron / TIBC) × 100.
Interpret results using the above thresholds to confirm iron deficiency.
